articles.title: Rare footage shows sucker fish as they whale-surf in the ocean's wildest joyride
articles.summary: Remora fish ride a humpback whale off the coast of south-east Queensland, Australia, on June 15, 2024. New for subscribers? Gift this article to your friends and family for free.   It's cms.site.custom.site_domain : stcatharinesstandard.ca sWebsitePrimaryPublication : publications/st_catharaines_standard bHasMigrated.avatar : false.

articles.title: Climate Wetlands Community Restoration
articles.author: 이상대 중년 홈트
articles.summary: Joel Caldwell, Raya Scott, Agnes Suárez and Land are observing pollinators in Charleston, S.C. on Tuesday, Oct. 7, 2025. The group is part of the Climate Wetlands Community Restoration Restoration Project.

articles.title: Tracking another warming trend
articles.author: Melissa Zaremba
articles.summary: It was another warm and mild afternoon. Overnight lows will dip down into the upper 50s by Saturday morning. Dry and warm weather will prevail through the middle of next week for the Desert Southwest. It will be a sunny and dry weekend with highs warming back to the low 90s into early next week.

articles.title: COP30 Climate Summit
articles.author: Citrus County Chronicle
articles.summary: Construction workers prepare the venue for the COP30 U.N. Climate Summit, Friday, Nov. 7, 2025, in Belem, Brazil, to be held at COP30 in November 30th, 30th of each year.

articles.title: Author and Longshoreman John Tronrud Publishes Memoir Celebrating Five Decades of Alaska's Maritime Heritage
articles.author: Ein News
articles.summary: A Constantly Changing Tide is a memoir written by John Tronrud, a retired longshoreman from Skagway, Alaska. John served three terms as a city councilman and is an elder at the First Presbyterian Church. John has a passion for hands-on projects and has built three homes and restored a fire-damaged 1902 historic building.

articles.title: Caribbean groups in CT want help sending donations to Jamaica following Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Connecticut Public Radio
articles.summary: Caribbean organizations in Connecticut are asking the governor's office for help in sending donated items to Jamaica following the devastation caused by Hurricane Melissa. The local groups are trying to fill 25 barrels with donated items for those who've lost everything during the storm. Each barrel can fit about a month's worth of groceries for one household and costs approximately $145 to ship. Community leaders say they're about halfway through filling the barrels and hope to send the first shipment by November 30.

articles.title: Croplands shrink amid rising salinity in Bagerhat-
articles.author: Partha Chakrabortty
articles.summary: The coastal district of Bagerhat has undergone a sweeping transformation over the past decade. The vast stretches of cropland used for paddy cultivation have been converted into aquaculture ponds. The boom in shrimp farming has brought prosperity for large leaseholders and investors through lucrative export markets. Small farmers and day labourers have faced displacement and rising debts as their farmlands can no longer support crops because of high salinity.

articles.title: People in glass houses
articles.author: Letters
articles.summary: Barnaby Joyce and NSW Premier Minns want to forcibly acquire farmers' land for a controversial gas pipeline. The East Coast does not stand to gain from more gas production. Domestic gas from the Narrabri project will cost almost 50 per cent more than from Santos' Gladstone gas project in Queensland. Gas is a dangerous pollutant that is fueling the effects of climate change.

articles.title: Montreal's Jamaican community rallies to help hurricane victims back home
articles.author: Maya Johnson
articles.summary: Montreal's Jamaican community is rallying to collect money and supplies for the victims of Hurricane Melissa. The Jamaica Association of Montreal will host a Hurricane Relief Open Mic Night on Saturday, Nov. 8 at 4 p.m. at its headquarters at 4065 Jean-Talon West.

articles.title: Why young people are fleeing Australia
articles.summary: Most young people are considering a move abroad to escape housing costs in Australia, according to new data. Australia risks losing a generation of young people due to high housing costs.      Â   .   in Australia.  in

articles.title: Extreme heat threatens long-term health as temperatures rise across US
articles.author: Parker King
articles.summary: The summer of 2025 saw a number of extreme heat-related events and above-average temperatures across most of the lower 48 United States. Since 2018, several major heatwaves have affected the U.S., including a record-shattering event in the Pacific Northwest. The average number of heatwaves has doubled since the 1980s and the length of the heatwave season has increased from about 40 to 70 days.

articles.title: A change of priorities
articles.summary: The Coastal Resilience Committee was formed to take the project to the next level. The committee is made up of town staff, GIS Coordinator and former Town Planner Alison Ring and Public Works Director Mike Shea, and representatives from GZA Environmental. They have been working with the Rhode Island Infrastructure Bank and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Foundation.

articles.title: Maryland Lawmakers with Jamaican Roots Rally Support for Hurricane Melissa Relief
articles.author: Suzanne Pollak
articles.summary: Both of Councilmember Sayles' parents were born in Jamaica. Her mother lives in Falmouth, Jamaica, most of the year. Hurricane Melissa made landfall in Jamaica on October 28, causing widespread damage. There is no electricity, clean water or phone service in some parts of the island. Sayles hopes her mother will return to America for Thanksgiving.

articles.title: Education for a resilient and sustainable future: strengthening climate change education in Cambodia (UNESCO
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Climate change is a global challenge. In Cambodia, its effects are visible with extreme weather, droughts, and floods causing disruptions to daily life, public and livelihoods. It is threatening both the environment and human livelihoods, according to the UNFCCC.

articles.title: Citing rising tides, the State plans to demolish shacks at Island Beach State Park
articles.author: Peter Ackerman
articles.summary: Fishing shacks on Island Beach State Park in New Jersey are slated for demolition due to rising sea levels due to climate change. The Judge's Shack, which is believed to have been built around 1911, will remain standing. Six cottages are slated to be torn down in 2025.

articles.title: Thread by @ChrisMartzWX on Thread Reader App
articles.summary: There is a myth that 97% of climate scientists agree that all global warming since the mid-19th century is human-caused. The 'consensus of scientists' is not organic. It was manufactured through questionable data processing methods in two studies published in Environmental Research Letters (ERL).

articles.title: Letter to the Editor: Appealing to Gov. Moore for resonsideration
articles.summary: FEMA has denied funds for flood relief in Garrett and Allegany County following the devastating flooding on May 13, 2025. Rev. Ed Clemons Jr. is concerned that nearly six months have passed without a viable solution being put in place by the federal and state governments. He urges Governor Moore to convene a special session to expedite the release of funding for heating system replacement and deploy state resources for water, sewer and roadway repair and replacement.

articles.title: Big countries make it harder for us Jamaicans to survive big storms
articles.author: Christopher Boxe
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa hit Jamaica last week. Kingston was spared the worst of the storm, but the western parishes of St. Elizabeth and Westmoreland bore the brunt of the devastation. The Caribbean bears a disproportionate burden in the global climate crisis. Jamaica pioneered the 'cat-in-a-grid' catastrophe bond.

articles.title: Leaders at the Global Climate Summit Highlight the Rising Toll of Warming
articles.author: David Gelles
articles.summary: World leaders are at the United Nations climate summit in Belém, Brazil. They are talking about the effects of climate change. The United Nations announced this week that the world is off-track from keeping global warming well below 2 degrees Celsius. The world is on track to warm by roughly 2.8 degrees Celsius, according to scientists.

articles.title: Residents of Alaska's storm-battered Native towns consider moving to higher ground
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Typhoon Halong has damaged villages in western Alaska and highlighted the vulnerability of the villages to climate change.      Â   .   in Alaska to climate crisis, as a result of Typhoon Halong's damage, which underscored the vulnerability.

articles.title: The Guardian view on worsening extreme weather: the injustice of the climate crisis grows ever clearer
articles.author: Editorial
articles.summary: The current death toll across the Caribbean is at least 75. The economic and social costs are hard to quantify in a region that is still recovering from Hurricane Beryl. Small island states have their own group (The Alliance of Small Island States) and distinctive voice in the Cop30 climate process. Donald Trump's withdrawal of the US from the climate process was a setback.

articles.title: Africa: On the Road to Cop 30 - the African Development Bank Group Is Piloting ...
articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: The African Development Bank Group is concerned about the climate crisis, especially for the most vulnerable countries. It is working with the UNFCCC to help vulnerable countries to tackle climate change.       .   for the poorest countries and for the environment.

articles.title: At U.N. climate summit, world leaders say time is running short to stop worst effects of warming
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: U.N. Secretary-General António Guterres opened a gathering of heads of state in Belem, Brazil, with harsh words for world powers who 'remain captive to the fossil fuel interests, rather than protecting the public interest.' Allowing global warming to exceed the key benchmark of 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) would represent a 'moral failure and deadly negligence'

articles.title: COP30 in Brazil: Africa Pushes for Real Climate Action
articles.author: Oumaima Moho Amer
articles.summary: The 30th United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP30) is taking place in Belém, Brazil. It is the first so-called 'Implementation COP' since the Paris Agreement's adoption a decade ago. Africa's climate adaptation costs are estimated at $70 billion per year, yet only $14.8 billion in funding reached the continent in 2023. The losses and damages caused by climate change are projected to cost between $290 billion and $440 billion by 2030.

articles.title: Earth Matters: Check out the scary Emissions Gap Report; plus Michael E. Mann slams Bill Gates
articles.author: Meteor Blades
articles.summary: This year's UNEP Emissions Gap Report shows a slight improvement in predictions from the 2024 report. However, the world is headed for 2.8°C of warming by 2100, compared to 3.1°C in the previous report. The current situation is "leaving the world heading for serious escalation of climate risks".

articles.title: Rising Nighttime Heat Threatens African Cities, New Global Study Warns
articles.author: Emmanuel Gameli Dovia
articles.summary: A new study shows that nighttime temperatures are rising at alarming rates across major cities worldwide. In Africa, 13 of 15 cities studied showed significant increases in nighttime temperatures during moist tropical weather, while 10 of 14 recorded similar increases during dry tropical conditions. Agadir, Morocco and Cairo, Egypt are among the fastest-warming cities. The frequency of extreme heat events is on the rise.

articles.title: Analysis: Climate change boosted hurricane
articles.author: Muscatine Journal
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change boosted the destructive winds and rain unleashed by Hurricane Melissa and increased the temperatures and humidity that fueled the storm, according to an analysis released Thursday. The analysis was based on data from the U.S. National Center for Atmospheric Research.

articles.title: The climate crisis demands healthy solutions
articles.author: Ludwig Federigan
articles.summary: The 9th annual report of the Lancet Countdown on Health and Climate Change was released on Oct. 29, 2025. Heat-related fatalities have surged by 63 percent since the 1990s. The year 2024 witnessed the devastating impact of wildfire smoke, directly linked to a record-breaking 154,000 deaths. The burning of fossil fuels is linked to an estimated 2.5 million deaths annually resulting from air pollution. The report underscores the positive impact of climate action already in motion.

articles.title: Plane crew captures stunning Aurora Borealis while flying over Norway
articles.author: Dean Murray
articles.summary: The crew of the A400M Atlas from XXIV Squadron was flying over Norway on Saturday, Nov. 1. They were conducting training and operations over the region. The Aurora Borealis is a natural light display caused by charged solar particles interacting with the Earth's atmosphere and magnetic field.

articles.title: Why this isn't like past storms: a slow-motion crisis in Buxton and beyond
articles.author: Joy Crist
articles.summary: Since September 16, 15 houses in Buxton have fallen into the Atlantic Ocean and one in Rodanthe. Five houses collapsed in a single day twice within one month, on September 30 and again on October 28. 27 oceanfront homes have fallen since 2020. Cape Hatteras Elementary and Secondary Schools have canceled, delayed, or converted to remote learning more than a dozen times in the first 48 days of the year.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa causes over J$20 billion in damage to Jamaica's agriculture sector
articles.author: Cnw Reporter
articles.summary: Jamaica's agriculture sector has suffered catastrophic damage from Hurricane Melissa, with losses already estimated to exceed J$20 billion. The Ministry of Agriculture has activated its recovery plan, focusing on stabilizing incomes and restoring production in the worst-affected communities. FAO has deployed a disaster assessment specialist to support the recovery process and guide the technical response.

articles.title: Díaz-Canel acknowledges severe damage from Hurricane Melissa but insists that "recovery is progressing."
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Miguel Díaz-Canel visited Santiago de Cuba and met with residents of Urbano Noris and Cacocum, the hardest hit by Hurricane Melissa. More than 10,000 homes in Holguín have been affected by the winds and flooding from Hurricane Melissa, according to the leader. The UN announced on Thursday an action plan aimed at raising 74.2 million dollars to assist one million people in eastern Cuba.

articles.title: Climate Issue newsletter: China, the climate superpower
articles.author: Oliver Morton
articles.summary: It's hard to see the Paris agreement's first decade as a resounding success. This year will be the second- or third-hottest year on record, extending the run of exceptional temperatures that kicked off in 2023. China's 'Made in China 2025' programme, which dates to 2015, has had heartening results from its proponents' perspective. It has driven down the price of solar panels by a factor of 20, and it is adding capacity at a rate of between 500 gigawatts and a terawatt a year.

articles.title: New Study: Greenland Ice Melt Still Defies Alarmist Warming Claims
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: Greenland temperature stations indicate an abrupt 2.9°C warming trend from 1922 to 1932. Between 1993 and 2007, the warming trend was 3°C. There has been almost zero net warming across Greenland in the last century. Greenland ice sheet melt has added just 1 cm to global sea levels since 1900.

articles.title: 2025 ‘almost certain' to be one of the three hottest years on record
articles.author: newsroom
articles.summary: The year 2025 is almost certain to rank as one of the three hottest years on record, according to an analysis released Thursday by the Copernicus Climate Change Service. October was the third-hottest October globally ever recorded, with an average temperature of 15.14C (59F). Last month's global average temperature was 1.55C (2.79F) higher than the pre-industrial average (1850-1900).

articles.title: City Experiences 25-Degree Temperatures Today, Expected to Drop to 5 Degrees Tomorrow
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Melbourne basked in a high of 28 degrees today. Tomorrow's forecast predicts a maximum of 13 degrees. The perceived temperature, factoring in wind and other elements, could feel as chilly as five degrees. According to Weatherzone, these rapid swings in temperature are not unusual during Melbourne's spring season.

articles.title: Reduced air pollution is accelerating global warming, claims study
articles.author: TOI Trending Desk
articles.summary: Earth is warming faster than predicted due to the reduction in air pollution. This is because the Earth is reflecting less sunlight and absorbing more heat. Between 2003 and 2022, clouds over the northeastern Pacific and Atlantic Oceans became nearly 3% less reflective per decade. 70% of this change is attributed to aerosols, which are fine particles that float through the atmosphere and influence both cloud cover and cloud composition.

articles.title: How rising Loss and Damage threatens Tanzania's economy, livelihoods
articles.author: Data Analyst
articles.summary: In Tanzania, the effects of loss and damage linked to climate change are already shaping people's daily lives and key sectors of the economy. Tanzania's former Vice President Dr Philip Mpango said that extreme weather events have devastated the lives and livelihoods of millions of people.

articles.title: The new climate reality and systemic financial risk
articles.author: New Statesman
articles.summary: In 2021, researchers at the World Bank assessed the risk to Pakistan's economy from climate change. In the worst case, the economy was projected to lose up to 10 per cent of GDP by the end of century's end, according to World Bank researchers.

articles.title: Cop 30 opens in Brazil
articles.summary: George Lee is at the United Nations annual climate change conference, COP 30. George Lee joins us now from the UN conference in Bonn. He is the environment correspondent for The Guardian newspaper.    for the Guardian newspaper is George Lee, the Guardian's environment correspondent.

articles.title: 2025 Set To Be Among Top 3 Warmest Years Ever Recorded: WMO; UN Chief Urges ...
articles.author: News18
articles.summary: WMO warns 2025 could be the second or third warmest year on record. Antonio Guterres urges action at Bel’m Climate Summit and COP30 in Brazil. WMO warns global temperatures could breach 1.5°C in 2025, which would be a record-breaking year.

articles.title: Jamaica Hurricane Relief: Operation Blessing Aids Victims
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa devastated Jamaica, killing 32 people and leaving most of the island without power. Over 120,000 structures suffered roof damage, leaving an estimated 140,000 Jamaicans without access to essential aid. The immediate impact of Melissa is staggering. The scale of destruction signals a rapidly escalating trend of extreme weather events. Climate change is driving increased internal displacement. Developed nations have a moral and economic imperative to support adaptation efforts in vulnerable countries like Jamaica.

articles.title: Respectfully, Bill Gates Needs to Shut Up
articles.author: Nitish Pahwa
articles.summary: Bill Gates is calling for a 'strategic pivot' in the climate change fight. He doesn't seem to have publicly addressed the Hurricane Melissa that devastated the Caribbean. The world order that once notched international climate agreements isn't just retreating from that fight, but pulling back from any globally minded action altogether.

articles.title: Spain bans the raising of poultry outdoors due to increase in bird flu cases
articles.author: C. P. S.
articles.summary: The Spanish government has ordered a preventive measure that bans raising poultry outdoors as of 10 November. The aim is to curb the spread of the bird flu, which has been increasingly detected across Europe. The risk level has been growing in recent weeks. The flu has been affecting both wild and domestic birds in Northern and Central Europe.

articles.title: VICTOR JOECKS: Gates admits the ‘science deniers' were right
articles.summary: Bill Gates has changed his mind about global warming. He used his vast fortune to fund climate alarmism and wrote a book titled 'How to Avoid a Climate Disaster' Now he believes the world needs to focus on 'improving lives' rather than limiting the rise in temperature.

articles.title: BBC Falsely Blames Pakistan Floods On ‘Climate Change'
articles.author: Principia Scientific
articles.summary: Long-term records show no increase in monsoon severity, but rapid urban growth in flood zones worsens damage, according to the World Meteorological Agency (WMA).       .   in the past few decades, there has been an increase in the number of people living in flood-prone areas.

articles.title: Climate Change Alarm: Renowned NASA Scientist Warns of Atlantic Ocean Current System's Collapse Within 20-30 Years: Catastrophic Climate Impacts Loom – [your]NEWS
articles.author: Susmita
articles.summary: NASA scientists warned in 1988 that Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) might collapse within 20 to 30 years. The new study found many alarming things that show how the faster weather changes are increasing the risks of weather calamities. The main issue is the sleeping giant, the point of no return, the danger of an AMOC shutdown and large sea level rise.

articles.title: Chocolate, coffee and wine won't survive climate change, study predicts
articles.author: Julia Musto
articles.summary: Key growing regions for wine, coffee, and chocolate in western Europe, South America and West Africa are threatened by climate change. Stratospheric Aerosol Injection (SAI), a proposed method to cool Earth by pumping gas into the sky, will not be sufficient to save these luxury crops.

articles.title: Extreme heatwave turned Amazon river into inferno for dolphins
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: In 2023, a heatwave and drought turned the Amazon's lakes into simmering basins. The shallow Lake Tef reached a scorching 41C. The study analysed water temperature measurements from ten central Amazonian lakes during the 2023 drought. Amazon lakes have been warming by 0.3 to 0.8C per decade over the past 30 years. The broader Amazon region is under strain.

articles.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi havoc in SE Asia: Scientists blame rising temperature
articles.author: CGTN
articles.summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 188 people across the Philippines. The storm destroyed homes and uprooted trees after landing in central Vietnam, killing at least five people. The path of destruction coincides with a meeting of delegates from more than 190 countries in the rainforest city of Belem in Brazil for the latest round of climate talks.

articles.title: Homes are collapsing in North Carolina. It could spell trouble for other coastal areas, too
articles.author: Samantha Delouya
articles.summary: Stacy Morgan and Brandon Dodick bought their beach house in Buxton, North Carolina, in May. Five months later, their house was destroyed. Since 2020, 27 beachfront homes on Hatteras Island have collapsed into the ocean. Sixteen of the homes have collapsed since September, all of them unoccupied at the time. The safety net designed to financially protect homeowners from flooding is frozen amid the government shutdown. Lat Williams, who has lived on the same stretch of beach for 45 years, is relocating his home.

articles.title: Online Map Links Deforestation to Tropical Heat Rise
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Deforestation is leading to temperature increases of up to 5°C in some tropical regions, according to a new interactive map created by researchers at the University of Leeds. The tool was designed to highlight the important role forests play in moderating local climates. It was developed as part of the Climate Science for Services Partnership (CSSP) Brazil project. It is hosted by the Met Office on its CSSP Brazil VIEWpoint website.

articles.title: Advanced Breast Cancer Patients Living Longer, Study Says
articles.summary: There will be a mix of clouds and sun this morning followed by increasing clouds with showers developing this afternoon. High around 75F. Winds S at 5 to 10 mph. Rainfall could reach 70%, mainly in the afternoon. In the evening, there will be thunderstorms.

articles.title: The Next Decade Of Danger: How Crossing 1.5°C Climate Threshold Will Change The World?
articles.author: Tanya.Dutt
articles.summary: The world is no longer on track to limit global warming to 1.5°C. The global average temperature will exceed this threshold before 2035, potentially within the next decade. Within that half-degree lies the difference between adaptation and irreversible loss, according to the UN Environment Programme.

articles.title: Perth's bizarre quirks exposed by Irish expats
articles.summary: Kate and Connor Hannigan emigrated to Perth from Sydney for 11 months. They have lived in Sydney for 6 years and loved it there, but they can't get used to some of the quirks of the West Australian state. They took to Instagram to list the things they miss about Perth.

articles.title: Concussions Increase Traffic Crash Risk For Weeks After
articles.summary: There will be a mix of clouds and sun this morning followed by increasing clouds with showers developing this afternoon. High around 75F. Winds S at 5 to 10 mph. Rainfall could reach 70%, mainly in the afternoon. In the evening, there will be thunderstorms.

articles.title: Mongolia records coldest October since 1940
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: Mongolia reported its coldest October in 2025 since temperature records began, according to the National Agency for Meteorology and Environmental Monitoring.    in Xinhua's news agency. In the past, October has been coldest since records began in the early 1900s.

articles.title: As Global Climate Action Threatens to Stall, Can Australia Step up at COP30 in Brazil?
articles.summary: Ten years after Paris Agreement, countries have taken big strides in limiting emissions and the clean energy transition is accelerating rapidly. But geopolitical headwinds are growing and the damage bill for climate pollution is rising. Next week, negotiators gather in Brazil for COP30, the 30th annual global climate talks.

articles.title: Climate Doomism Seems to Be the Sole Product of the University of Pennsylvania's Center for Science, Sustainability, and the Media
articles.author: Energy Security
articles.summary: Doomism is alive and well at the University of Pennsylvania's Center for Science, Sustainability, and the Media. Bill Gates has been slammed for his anti-scientific memo calling for shifting our focus away from 'near-term' emissions cuts. The world's top scientists found in their 2023 IPCC assessment: 'The continuation of policies implemented by the end of 2020 leads to global warming of 3.2°C by 2100.'

articles.title: UN Warns 2025 to Be Among the Three Hottest Years Ever Recorded
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: The UN warns 2025 will be one of the top 3 hottest years, fueled by record greenhouse gases. The findings were shared just as world leaders were meeting in the Amazon region of Brazil, ahead of the upcoming COP30 climate summit. The goal of keeping warming below 1.5°C was established by the 2015 Paris Agreement.

articles.title: อุตุโลกฯเผย ปี 2568 จ่อติด 'ท็อป 3' ปีที่ร้อนสุดเป็นประวัติการณ์
articles.author: Napat Changamporn
articles.summary: From January to August 2025, average temperature was +1.42°C hotter than pre-industrial level. It's on track to be second or third hottest year on record. State of Climate Update 2025 is out now. It is available on Twitter and on the Press Release website.

articles.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi brings rain and destruction to Vietnam as death toll nears 200 in Philippines
articles.summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi dumped one-and-a-half months' worth of rainfall in a day in Cebu on Tuesday. More than 560,000 people evacuated, 450,000 sheltered, and six people died when a Philippine air force helicopter crashed. President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. declared a state of emergency to speed emergency funds and curb hoarding.

articles.title: ‘Politicians actually taking action': five world mayors defying climate-sceptic populist leaders
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Cities are introducing their own rules and innovations in the face of rising temperatures. From Sierra Leone to Milan, cities are introducing new rules to cope with the rising temperatures, such as in Sierra Leone and Milan, and in some places even introducing new laws and regulations.

articles.title: 2025 Set To Be Among Top 3 Warmest Years Ever Recorded: WMO; UN Chief Urges Rapid Action
articles.author: Manisha Roy
articles.summary: WMO warns 2025 could be the second or third warmest year ever, with global temperatures breaching 1.5°C. Antonio Guterres urges action at Belém Climate Summit and COP30 in Brazil. The period from 2015 to 2025 will mark the warmest 11 years in recorded history, with the last three years the hottest ever observed.

articles.title: MoBay Community College facing long, long closure
articles.author: Horace Hines
articles.summary: Montego Bay Community College's main campus in Montego Bay suffered widespread and multi-layered damage as a result of Hurricane Melissa. The registry building, which houses the principal's and vice-principals' offices, has severe roof failure and water intrusion. The auditorium, which connects 83 classrooms and labs, is significantly damaged, and the lecture theatre has major roofing loss. The administrative block lost its roof, two classrooms and two computer labs were severely damaged and the staff room and guidance counselling offices also sustained roofing failure. The Llandillo Special School of Special Education in Westmoreland also lost several roofs and will need major repair. Prime Minister Andrew Hol

articles.title: How Much Suffering Can COP30 Prevent?
articles.author: Mark Hertsgaard
articles.summary: The UN climate summit in Belém, Brazil kicks off on Monday. UN Secretary General António Guterres has warned that global warming is unstoppable and will be 'devastating' for the world's most vulnerable communities if it doesn't slow down.

articles.title: ‘Hurtling Toward Climate Chaos' as COP30 Nears
articles.author: Bob Berwyn
articles.summary: Earth's natural carbon-absorbing systems, including forests and oceans, are breaking down in the face of relentlessly rising greenhouse gas levels from fossil fuel emissions. Failure to cut greenhouse gas emissions in the decade since the Paris Agreement has added more heat to the pipeline that, by 2050, will push the global temperature up to 1.7 degrees Celsius above the late 1800s global average. Oil Change International, a nonprofit fossil fuel industry watchdog group, suggests that four countries carry an especially hefty fossil fuel burden: the United States, Canada, Australia and Norway.

articles.title: Hey so one day the ocean might burp up a bunch of heat
articles.author: Matt Simon
articles.summary: Since the Industrial Revolution, humans have been adding a lot of CO2 to the atmosphere. The Southern Ocean holds 80% of the Earth's heat and has taken up a quarter of our CO2 emissions. New modeling suggests that this 'burp' of heat could be abrupt. In a scenario where humanity eventually reduces its greenhouse gas emissions and then goes 'net negative', the Southern Ocean belches its accumulated heat into the atmosphere, leading to planetary warming.

articles.title: After Hurricane Melissa, Jamaica's climate resilience plan faces its biggest test yet
articles.author: Grist
articles.summary: Trelawney Parish in Western Jamaica is devastated by the aftermath of Hurricane Melissa. The parish borders the country's largest contiguous rainforest and is usually green, but now it's brown.    "Everything here is brown right now. It looks like California."

articles.title: UN Secretary General warns of red line for humanity — online.ua
articles.summary: A global temperature increase of 1.5°C is a "red line for humanity" according to UN Secretary-General António Guterres. Failure to curb global warming poses environmental risks and moral implications. New research shows that a temporary exceedance of the limit is inevitable starting from the early 2030s.

articles.title: Mozambique Harnesses AI To Modernize Early Warning Systems For Climate Resilience
articles.summary: Mozambique is investing in early warning and disaster preparedness capabilities. It is using artificial intelligence and digital technology to improve its early warning system. The country has faced escalating climate challenges in recent years. It was hit by tropical cyclones Chido, Dikeledi, and Jude during the 2024-2025 rainy season.

articles.title: Greenland Ice Hysteria Melts Away When Real World Research Takes Over from Modeling
articles.author: Thomas J Shepstone
articles.summary: John Robson takes on Greenland ice hysteria in the way only he can in the 14-minute video he made with the help of a video camera. It's a good one. Enjoy it.      Â  “Enjoy”

articles.title: Next Birds & Brews heads to Falkland Islands
articles.author: Alex Veiga
articles.summary: The next Birds & Brews event will whisk attendees to the Falkland Islands to learn more about penguins on Wednesday, Nov. 19, at 5 p.m. at the RiverWalk Brewery, 40 Parker St., Newburyport. The Falklands are a remote South Atlantic archipelago with two main islands, East and West Falkland, plus 776 smaller islands.

articles.title: UN says 2025 was among the hottest years on record
articles.author: Gazeta Express
articles.summary: UN says 2025 was among the hottest years on record. The years between 2015 and 2025 have individually been the hottest since weather observations began 176 years ago. The Paris climate agreement aimed to limit global warming to less than two degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to 1.5 degrees Celsius, if possible. Leaders have yet to fulfill their commitments from the agreement.

articles.title: UNSC Urges More Support for Climate-Conflict Links
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Today is International Day for Preventing the Exploitation of the Environment in War and Armed Conflict. The Security Council heard a wide-ranging discussion on climate and security. Francessie Alghali, Sierra Leone's Deputy Minister for Foreign Affairs and International Council President, reflected on her country's experience following its war. Inger Andersen, Under-Secretary-General and Executive Director of the UNEP, highlighted various "soft law" instruments. Charles C. Jalloh, Professor, University of Miami Law School and Member of the International Law Commission, called for a more coherent legislative framework.

articles.title: Africa at COP30: Hard-hit continent demands world put words into action
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Africa is heading to the 30th UN Climate Change Conference (COP30) in Belem, Brazil. The continent seeks real funding, equitable rules and a voice that matches its stakes in the global climate debate. Africa's message is 'Africa's ambition'

articles.title: 11 Hottest Years on Record Mark Moral Failure in Reducing Emissions
articles.author: Ahmad Arif
articles.summary: The last three years are the hottest on record, with the average temperature near the surface from January to August 2025 reaching 1.42 degrees Celsius. The concentration of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased from 278 parts per million (ppm) in 1750 to 423.9 ppm in 2024, an increase of 53 percent. The global average concentration of CH4 increased from 729 parts per billion (ppb) to 1,942 ppb in 2024. The long-term rate of sea level rise has increased since the beginning of satellite records.

articles.title: Virgin Australia flight catches fire on arrival at Brisbane Airport
articles.author: Uniindia News Service
articles.summary: A fire broke out in the brakes of a Virgin Australia flight shortly after landing at Brisbane Airport on Thursday night. None of the 178 passengers and crew on board the flight were injured. The incident did not cause any delays and is not expected to impact scheduled flights on Friday. Bangladesh universities see protests over scrapping of teaching posts for music and physical education. NATO chief urges member-nations to boost military production.

articles.title: Closing the climate ambition gap: A call to global leaders, govts, businesses and citizens
articles.summary: The UNEP Copenhagen Climate Centre Emissions Gap Report 2025 shows that we are moving further away from the 1.5°C goal set under the Paris Agreement. Global emissions have reached a record 57.7 GtCO₂e, rising by 2.3% in a single year. Fossil fuels account for nearly 70% of total emissions, while deforestation and land-use change drive much of the remaining increase. The next phase of climate action will test not only global cooperation but the integrity of leadership itself. The COP30 summit must trigger an implementation revolution.

articles.title: Antarctica to lose its entire ice? Scientists warn the frozen continent is on the brink of collapse, alarming changes will leave you stunned
articles.author: Global Desk
articles.summary: Antarctica is on the brink of abrupt and irreversible changes affecting its ice sheets, oceans, and ecosystems. West Antarctic Ice Sheet is at extreme risk of collapse if atmospheric carbon dioxide levels continue to rise. A complete collapse of the WAIS could lead to a significant rise in global sea levels, putting coastal populations and major cities at risk. Emperor penguin populations are facing heightened extinction risks, as their chicks rely on stable sea ice to grow. Populations of krill, penguin and seal species could see significant declines. Key phytoplankton, which form the foundation of the Antarctic food web, are being disrupted by ocean warming and acidification.

articles.title: 2025 likely among warmest years on record: UN climate organization
articles.summary: The year 2025 is likely to be the second or third warmest year on record. Multinational automakers are showcasing their latest technological achievements at the ongoing 8th China International Import Expo in Shanghai. BMW's new products integrate AI large-model capabilities and customized AI agents to further expand in-vehicle digital ecosystem scenarios and functions. Volvo has exhibited at the CIIE for eight consecutive years.

articles.title: 2025 Set to Be Among Hottest Years Ever as WMO Warns of Escalating Climate Crisis
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has released its State of the Global Climate Update for 2025. According to the report, 2025 is on track to be the second or third warmest year ever recorded, capping an alarming trend of 11 consecutive years of record-breaking heat from 2015 to 2025. Oceans heat content continues to rise at an alarming rate, which accelerates melting of glaciers and sea ice and fuels sea level rise. Arctic sea ice extent declined to 4.6 million km² in September, and Arctic sea-ice extent was the third lowest on record in February and September. CO2 levels rose to 423.9 ppm in 2024, up 53% from pre

articles.title: 2025 is on track to be among the three warmest years on record
articles.author: Rebecca Ann Hughes
articles.summary: October 2025 was the third-warmest globally on record, according to data from the EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service. The month recorded an average surface air temperature of 15.14°C, 0.70°C above the 1991-2020 average for October. 2025 is virtually certain to finish as the second- or third- warmest year on record.

articles.title: Global ice loss dangerously expanding, billions under threat, warn scientists
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: The 2025 State of the Cryosphere Report was released ahead of the UN Climate Summit, COP30, in Belm, Brazil. It warns that current global climate pledges would lead to well over 2C of warming. Even 1C warming threatens the long-term stability of polar ice sheets and many mountain glaciers. The report's release coincides with the Climate Leaders Action Summit at COP30.

articles.title: Rising Global Temperatures Fuel Intensifying Typhoon Kalmaegi
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi hit central Vietnam after devastating the Philippines. Scientists warn that such severe storms are becoming more common due to rising global temperatures. The link between warmer sea temperatures and storm intensity was a key topic during climate discussions in Belem, Brazil.

articles.title: Australia's Role at COP30: Can It Lead Climate Action?
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Next week negotiators gather in Brazil for COP30, the 30th annual global climate talks. This year's talks could be pivotal, as all countries were due to set more ambitious targets to cut emissions. Australia's delegation will arrive in Belém with a much stronger target: cutting emissions 62-70% by 2035. Australia is also bidding to host the next COP talks with Pacific nations.

articles.title: The Rising Tide: Living with Water
articles.author: South Carolina ETV
articles.summary: Flooding from extreme weather and sea level rise is threatening SC's coastline. Host Thelisha Eaddy discusses the future of the Grand Strand to the Lowcountry on November 9th at 4:15 p.m. (minutest).

articles.title: Flood Stage: Sea Level Rise in Charleston
articles.author: South Carolina ETV
articles.summary: Flooding from sea level rise and overdevelopment is changing Charleston. Residents, officials and two historic Black communities are working to protect homes, culture and livelihoods in the face of a changing environment on WRLK on November 9th at 3:30 PM.

articles.title: A 'Brief' Cool-Down for 2025, but CO2 Concentrations Continue to Break Records
articles.author: Byeongku Lee
articles.summary: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has released its 'State of the Global Climate 2025' report. The global average temperature from January to August 2025 was 1.42±0.12°C above pre-industrial levels. This is lower than the 1.55°C recorded in the hottest year, 2024. Atmospheric carbon dioxide concentration increased by 53%, from 278 ppm in 1750 to 423.9 ppm in 2024. The increase from 2023 to 2024 was 3.5 ppm, the highest on record. Global mean sea level rose by 4.1 mm per year from 2016 to 2025.

articles.title: As Typhoon Kalmaegi wreaks havoc in Southeast Asia, scientists say rising temperatures are to blame, Asia News
articles.summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 188 people in the Philippines and caused untold damage to infrastructure and farmland across the archipelago. The storm then destroyed homes and uprooted trees after landing in central Vietnam late on Thursday. The path of destruction coincides with a meeting of delegates from more than 190 countries in the rainforest city of Belem in Brazil for the latest round of climate talks.

articles.title: 2025 on track to be among 3 warmest years
articles.author: Stella Meehan
articles.summary: October 2025 was the third-warmest October on record globally, with an average surface air temperature of 15.14°C, 0.70°C above the 1991-2020 average for October according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S). C3S is implemented by the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts on behalf of the European Commission with funding from the EU. The average global temperature for 2023–2025 is likely to exceed 1.5°C.

articles.title: Africa's Climate Crisis: AfDB Steps Up With Bold Financing to Build Resilience
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Africa receives less than 3% of global climate finance despite climate change shaving off 7% to 15% of Africa's GDP annually. The African Development Bank Group is a key actor in financing Africa's climate resilience and low-carbon development. The CIF has supported over $1 billion in financing for AfDB-led initiatives and $2.42 billion in co-financing. The ACCF has approved $40.64 million for 33 community-based projects. ACEF champions green, circular economies.

articles.title: What can cosmic dust tell us about the changing Arctic?
articles.author: Straits Times
articles.summary: The Arctic is rapidly transforming as global temperatures rise, as a result of climate change. The Arctic is changing rapidly due to rising global temperatures.   Â. Â   y   Y   in the Arctic is transforming as a consequence of global warming.

articles.title: Jamaica agricultural losses from Melissa reach J$20 billion and counting
articles.author: Stabroek News
articles.summary: Preliminary estimates of the losses across the agriculture and fisheries sector following Hurricane Melissa have totalled over j$20 billion so far. The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Mining has activated its recovery plan to stabilize incomes and begin restoration across the worst-affected communities. The Food and Agriculture Organization has deployed a disaster assessment specialist to support the technical response.

articles.title: Nearly a third of Jamaica's annual wealth wiped out by Hurricane Melissa (UNOG - United Nations Office at Geneva)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: 1.5 million Jamaicans have been impacted by Hurricane Melissa. It's the worst climate disaster in the Caribbean nation's history, according to UN development official in the region, who spoke to CNN on Thursday. It is estimated to be the worst hurricane in the history of the Caribbean.

articles.title: Killer hurricane Melissa's ferocity was fuelled by climate change
articles.author: Irish Independent
articles.summary: Climate change boosted the destructive winds and rain unleashed, according to the IPCC report. The IPCC claims that climate change is to blame for the weather disasters.      Â  ii   i   in the report,   y

articles.title: ‘There's a lot of disaster, a lot of pain in people right now': Hurricane victim in Jamaica speaks out
articles.author: WECT Staff
articles.summary: At least 32 people died in the Caribbean Islands due to Hurricane Melissa. Evangelist Mary Scott is organizing a way to send essential supplies to her friends on the island. She has been taking missionary trips to the island for the past 20 years. The church is preparing to send barrels containing clothes, non-perishable foods, and toiletries.

articles.title: 2025 Was The Third Hottest Years in History.
articles.author: Sumera Danish Zuberi
articles.summary: 2023, 2024, and 2025 are the hottest years in 176 years of record-keeping, according to the UN's World Meteorological Organisation. Concentrations of greenhouse gases have climbed to record highs, trapping more heat and pushing global temperatures to dangerous levels. UN Secretary-General António Guterres called the failure to curb temperature rise a 'moral failure'

articles.title: When the Earth hurts, we hurt: Understanding eco-anxiety and eco-grief
articles.author: Shobana Radhakrishnan
articles.summary: Cauviya and Samatha talk about eco-anxiety and eco-grief. They discuss the psychological impact of climate change and its psychological impact on different social groups. Samatha is a communications and programs professional based in India. She focuses on building narrative ecosystems across the Global South to make climate storytelling more cohesive and collaborative.

articles.title: UNEP Warns Earth Could Speed Past 1.5C Threshold by 2035 as COP30 Approaches
articles.author: Defara Dhanya
articles.summary: The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) has warned that the Earth will exceed the 1.5 degrees Celsius global warming threshold within the next ten years. UNEP believes the likelihood of achieving this target is very low due to inadequate mitigation efforts. Without significant changes, the world is projected to warm by 2.8 degrees Celsius by 2100. New commitments from countries such as China have "barely moved the needle" according to UNEP.

articles.title: Antarctica to lose its entire ice? Scientists warn the frozen continent is on the brink ...
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: Antarctica faces abrupt and irreversible changes impacting ice sheets, oceans and ecosystems. Scientists warn of global consequences for sea.    .   for sea and atmosphere.  For more information, visit: http://www.sciencemag.org/news/environmental-change/global-consequences-for-sea-and-asteroids/

articles.title: World leaders convene in Brazil to address climate crisis
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Leaders from China, US, India and Russia are absent from the gathering. UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres tore into nations for their failure to limit warming to. He said corporations are making record profits from climate devastation. They spend billions on lobbying and deceiving the public.

articles.title: Antarctica's Rapid Melting Could Trigger Global Sea Level Disaster
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: Scientists warn of irreversible changes in Antarctica's ice sheet melt, rising sea levels, and threats to wildlife. They urge urgent action on emissions to limit global warming to 1.5°C and prevent a global catastrophe. The West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) is melting at a dangerous rate. The loss of Antarctic sea ice makes the floating ice shelves vulnerable to collapse.

articles.title: Building Mental Resilience Against Climate Change
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Anna's friend escaped her home in the British Virgin Islands during Hurricane Irma in 2017. Eight years later, the aftermath of Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica has been particularly terrifying because of global warming. Psychologists Gulnaz Anjum and Mudassar Aziz describe how hurricanes like Irma and Melissa trigger a form of distress known as "deep anticipatory anxiety".

articles.title: Storm Surge: The Rising Threat of Tropical Cyclones
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Kalmaegi has struck central Vietnam after devastating the Philippines, killing 188 people. The typhoon's impact coincides with the global climate talks in Brazil. Scientists say climate change is fueling more violent storms.    The potential for catastrophic damage rises as the storms become more intense.

articles.title: As Typhoon Kalmaegi wreaks havoc in Southeast Asia, scientists say rising temperatures are to blame
articles.author: David Stanway
articles.summary: Typhoon Kalmaegi killed at least 188 people in the Philippines and caused untold damage to infrastructure and farmland across the archipelago. The storm hit central Vietnam late on Thursday. The path of destruction coincides with a meeting of delegates from more than 190 countries in the rainforest city of Belem in Brazil for the latest round of climate talks.

articles.title: Mozambique Calls for Greater Contribution From Most Polluting Countries
articles.summary: Roberto Albino is in Belém, capital of the Brazilian state of Pará on the sidelines of the latest Climate Change Summit (COP30). Mozambique will present concrete proposals to strengthen climate finance mechanisms and facilitate vulnerable countries' access to adaptation and mitigation funds.

articles.title: Peace with Nature Begins with an Amazon without Fossil Fuels
articles.author: El Pais
articles.summary: Nature is angry, as seen in the Caribbean after one of the most ferocious hurricanes ever recorded. Disasters like this bear the imprint of climate change driven by the extraction and use of fossil fuels, as well as natural disasters like this are no longer exceptions.

articles.title: ‘Hope the dog dies, Louise!' Why do we lose our minds over parking?
articles.summary: Parking derangement syndrome causes people to change their plans, move homes, or just not go out. Australians seem to be particularly susceptible to this syndrome, according to the experts.   Â. Â   y   i

articles.title: Calls for urgent climate commitment
articles.summary: Fiji is taking a hard line ahead of the COP30 climate summit in Brazil. The country's top priority is to demand that all countries strengthen their national emission targets under a proposed global NDC response plan. The second priority focuses on adaptation. The third priority is ocean-climate action. Fiji will co-chair negotiations to guide the operationalisation of the new loss and damage fund.

articles.title: ‘Unprecedented streak of high temperatures': 2025 set to be among top three warmest years, says World Meteorological Organization
articles.author: Express News Service
articles.summary: The near-surface temperature recorded between January and August this year was 1.42 degrees Celsius above the pre-industrial era. Last year was the warmest on record. The period between 2015 and 2025 would have been the 11 warmest years in the 176-year observational record.

articles.title: Global ice loss concerning: Report
articles.author: Deccan Herald
articles.summary: The current climate commitments are unambitious, according to the latest assessment. The world is already warming by over 2°C. Global ice loss could be a disaster for billions of people, but it can still be prevented, says the assessment.

articles.title: 2025 Set to Be Among 3 Warmest Years on Record: EU Climate Monitor
articles.author: Proceso Digital
articles.summary: The year 2025 will be the second or third warmest ever recorded, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service (C3S), which is the climate monitoring component of the European space program. The entry anticipates it will be warmest year ever recorded.

articles.title: Global ice loss concerning: Report
articles.author: Mrityunjay Bose
articles.summary: Just 1°C of warming is needed for stability of polar ice sheets and even lower temperatures for many glaciers, according to the 2025 State of the Cryosphere Report. The threshold is likely to be reached at just 1 °C of warmest. The research is detailed in the report.

articles.title: Urgent call from global scientists: climate change threatens health and food security
articles.author: Sheree Bega
articles.summary: S20 warns that climate change is endangering human health, food systems and ecosystems worldwide. The statement notes that since the industrial era, human activities have been the primary driver of climate change. 2024 was the warmest year on record. S20 recommends addressing the interconnected health of humans, animals, and ecosystems, climate, food and water security, energy, biodiversity and pollution.

articles.title: State rolls out plan for coastal protection
articles.author: Christian M. Wade
articles.summary: Rising seas and storms fueled by climate change threaten Massachusetts' coastal communities. State and local leaders are seeking protections to harden the shoreline from the worst impacts. On Thursday, the state released its ResilientCoasts plan, which outlines the state's strategy to address vulnerability to coastal hazards over the next 50 years.

articles.title: 2025 set to be among 3 warmest years on record: EU climate monitor
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: This year is almost certain to rank among the three warmest on record. October 2025 will be the third-warmest October globally. The average for 2023-2025 is likely to exceed 1.5 degrees Celsius for the first time for a three-year period.

articles.title: How Big Is Australia? Visualizing How Many Countries Fit Inside
articles.author: Tyler Durden
articles.summary: Australia is the sixth-largest country in the world, with a population of 27 million people. Its landmass is roughly equivalent to the combined size of nine countries, including 7th-ranked India. It's the size of the contiguous U.S. west of the Mississippi River. The population density is 9 people per square mile.

articles.title: Australia Backs Climate-Smart Agriculture at COP30
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Australia is attending the United Nations Climate Change Conference, COP30 in Belem, Brazil. It is committed to driving climate action in the agriculture, fisheries and forestry sectors. DAFF will share its experiences, innovations and learn from others to build a more resilient and sustainable future for all.

articles.title: Vietnam's flooding crisis reveals flaws in urban planning and infrastructure
articles.author: Vietnamnet News
articles.summary: The government and global experts stress digital tools, real-time weather systems and urban resilience for climate change adaptation for adaptation to climate change. The government and experts emphasize digital tools and real time weather systems for adaptation. The experts stress urban resilience and urban digital tools for adaptation as well.

articles.title: COP30 grapples with weakening global push on climate change
articles.summary: World leaders are gathering at the heart of the Amazon for global climate summit COP30 in Belem, Brazil. Earth is set to surpass 1.5 C of warming in the next decade. There is a climate change skeptic in the White House and worry that global co-operation to fight climate change is collapsing.

articles.title: UN Chief Urges Leaders to Curb Global Warming
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: 2025 on track to be among the hottest years on record, according to the WMO's State of the Global Climate Update 2025. It warns that the 11-year stretch from 2015 to 2025 will be the hottest period since records began 176 years ago. WMO chief Celeste Saulo says greenhouse gas emissions are at their highest level in 800,000 years. Marinez Scherer, Special Envoy for the Ocean, urges nations to unite efforts for both forests and oceans.

articles.title: UN launches US$74 million hurricane relief fund for Cuba
articles.summary: The United Nations has launched a US$74 million fund to aid Cuba in the wake of the destruction caused by Hurricane Melisa. An estimated 2.2 million Cubans are in need of assistance. In Haiti, around 16,000 people have been displaced and 43 people have died as a result of the hurricane. The UN's World Food Programme needs around US$18 million to assist 190,000 in Haiti.

articles.title: 30 years of climate talks: Progress, pitfalls and a planet in peril, World News
articles.summary: Three decades after the first annual climate conference, greenhouse gas emissions have increased by 34 per cent since 1995. Fossil fuel consumption continues to rise and global temperatures are on track to breach thresholds scientists say will unleash catastrophic damage to the planet. President Donald Trump has slashed subsidies for wind and solar power and electric vehicles, added permitting obstacles to renewable projects and opened more lands to drilling and mining.

articles.title: Massachusetts Launches 50-Year Plan to Protect Coastal Communities from Climate Risks
articles.author: Boston Real Estate Times
articles.summary: The Healey-Driscoll Administration released the ResilientCoasts Plan, a long-term strategy to safeguard Massachusetts' 1,500 miles of coastline from climate change. The plan outlines a comprehensive approach to protecting people, property, and natural environments over the next 50 years. It provides a blueprint for smarter investments in coastal resilience that could save billions in avoided damages and recovery costs.

articles.title: 2025 to be among warmest years on record
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: 2015 and 2025 will be the warmest years since observations began 176 years ago, according to the World Meteorological Organization. Concentrations of greenhouse gases grew to new record highs, locking in more heat for the future. The 2015 Paris climate accords aimed to limit global warming to well below two degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to 1.5C if possible.

articles.title: Tracing humanity's coastal journey from Africa
articles.author: The Jakarta Post
articles.summary: The origins and migrations of modern humans around the world are a hot topic of debate. Genetic analyses have pointed to Africa as the continent from which our ancestors dispersed in the Late Pleistocene epoch, which began about 126,000 years ago, and Africa is where modern humans came from.

articles.title: Weather Insdier: Global tipping points
articles.author: Spencer Blum
articles.summary: As the planet continues to warm, we run the risk of irreversibly changing several environmental systems across the planet. A recent report found that 80% of the Earth's coral reefs have been affected. Scientists are also monitoring ocean circulations in the Atlantic, melting ice sheets, die-backs in tropical rainforests like the Amazon.

articles.title: Loss of consensus lamented at UN climate summit
articles.author: Isabel Debre
articles.summary: World leaders are warning that time is running short for urgent and decisive action on climate change. Several are critical of the US for its retreat from those efforts, especially on the climate change issue, and are calling on it to do more to help the cause.

articles.title: There's going to be a showdown over environmental laws
articles.author: Jennifer Hewett
articles.summary: Environment Minister Murray Watt is determined to get a deal on Australia's environmental protection laws by Christmas, but it's a lot harder than it sounds and it's been unravelling over years.    - The Australian Greens want to change the law to make it more progressive.

articles.title: Hurricane left millions of tons of debris in Jamaica
articles.summary: Melissa was one of the most powerful hurricanes to ever hit Jamaica and has caused the worst climate disaster in the island's history. The damage from the storm is estimated to be the equivalent of 30 percent of Jamaica's GDP. 32 people died in Jamaica as a result of the storm.

articles.title: This is how the neighborhood of Jarahueca in Songo-La Maya looks after the passage of Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa destroyed 17 homes in Jarahueca in Songo-La Maya, Cuba. Similar scenes of destruction and abandonment can be observed in Santiago de Cuba, Granma, Holguín, Guantánamo, and Las Tunas. The humanitarian response has mainly come from civil society, churches, community groups, and Cubans in exile.

articles.title: 2025 Could Be 2nd or 3rd Warmest Year Ever
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The past 11 years, 2015 to 2025, have been the warmest years in the 176-year observational record. The mean near-surface temperature in January-August 2025 was 1.42 °C above the pre-industrial average. Concentrations of heat-trapping greenhouse gases and ocean heat content continued to rise in 2025. Arctic sea ice extent after the winter freeze was the lowest on record. Antarctic sea ice was well below average throughout the year. The number of countries reporting multi-hazard early warning systems has more than doubled since 2015.

articles.title: Global climate action losing momentum: OECD
articles.author: Ryan Cropp
articles.summary: Only 17.7% of global emissions are covered by legally binding net zero pledges according to the OECD's annual Climate Action Monitor. Coalition wrangling over its commitment to emissions reduction is likely to turbocharge the Coalition's efforts to address climate change. The expansion of international climate policy commitments increased by just 1% in 2024.

articles.title: Nearly a third of Jamaica's annual wealth wiped out by Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: system
articles.summary: 1.5 million Jamaicans have been affected by Hurricane Melissa. It's the worst climate disaster in the Caribbean nation's history, according to the top UN development official in the region on Thursday. The storm hit on Wednesday and hit the east coast of Jamaica.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa causes damage equivalent to 30% of Jamaica's GDP, UN reports
articles.author: Dimsum Daily Newsroom
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa destroyed 30% of Jamaica's gross domestic product and killed 32 people. The storm's impact has affected 1.5 million people across the Caribbean nation. The UN has allocated $400,000 to support preliminary damage assessments and provide immediate assistance to national partners. UN World Food Programme has airlifted food supplies to 6,000 households from Barbados.

articles.title: Human biomass movement 40x greater than all land animals combined
articles.author: The Hindu Bureau
articles.summary: The Arctic tern travels from pole to pole every year, covering 90,000 km back and forth. The migration of over a million blue wildebeest, gazelles, and zebras of the Serengeti constitutes an annual biomass movement 20 times larger than that of the grey wolf. Biomass movement of humans is 4,000 gt/km/yr. The combined biomass movement of wild land mammals, arthropods and birds is 30 gt per km.

articles.title: Shocking Climate Change Effects on Oceans: What You Need to Know
articles.author: Jeff Tomas
articles.summary: Earth's oceans cover 70% of the planet and support billions of people, but they are changing fast due to human-driven climate change. Sea surface temperatures have increased by about 0.88°C since the late 1800s, and the last decade was the hottest. The Great Barrier Reef has lost about half its corals over the last 30 years. Tuna and mackerel are moving toward higher latitudes, leaving fishers in the Gulf of Thailand with smaller catches. The IPCC warns that the global economic hit could reach $1 trillion by 2100.

articles.title: The Minister of Economy states that there are no injuries in Cuba following the passage of Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa passed through the eastern part of Cuba. The minister of economy and planning said that there were no deaths or injuries. The UN and humanitarian organizations report severe damage to over 60,000 homes, 1,500 schools, and hundreds of medical centers. The affected population reports the lack of food, medicine, and adequate shelters.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa causes damage in Jamaica equivalent to 30% of GDP: UN official
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa caused 30 percent of Jamaica's GDP damage. 32 people have died in Jamaica and 1.5 million people have been affected by the hurricane. UN has allocated 400,000 U.S. dollars to assist with basic assessment work and provide early support to national partners. UN World Food Programme is airlifting food from Barbados to support more than 6,000 households for up to a week.

articles.title: 2025 set to be among 3 warmest years on record: EU climate monitor
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: This year is almost certain to rank among the three warmest on record. October 2025 will be the third-warmest October globally, according to EU's Copernicus Climate Change Service. The 12-month average from November 2024 to October 2025 stood 1.50 degrees above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Experts urge special policies to safeguard Mekong Delta amid climate challenges
articles.author: Vietnam News
articles.summary: Experts have urged the Government to introduce special policies and dedicated financial mechanisms to help the Mekong Delta adapt to the growing impact of climate change. The region needs a comprehensive and long-term support mechanism, including a dedicated central budget for climate adaptation projects through 2030.

articles.title: Amazon Lakes Reached 105 Degrees, Killing Dolphins and Fish in Extreme Heat Wave
articles.author: Newsource
articles.summary: November 6, 2025 Amazon lakes Lake Tef Brazil heat wave Amazon drought climate change dolphin deaths Mamirau Institute Ayan Fleischmann global warming environmental study CNN Newsource. Link Copied to Clipboard!    Local & Community > Local & Community

articles.title: Mongolia records coldest October since 1940
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Mongolia reported its coldest October in 2025 since temperature records began. The average temperature last month was 4.5 degrees Celsius lower than a year earlier and 2.9 degrees below the long-term average. It was the lowest October temperature since 1940. Mongolia has an extreme continental climate characterized by long, cold winters and short, hot summers.

articles.title: The Myths We're Told About Climate Change
articles.author: American Thought Leaders
articles.summary: This episode will premiere on Nov. 8, 2025 at 5 p.m. ET. Bill Gates has recently publicly pivoted on climate change, rejecting 'doomsday' predictions and calling for a more pragmatic, human-centered approach. Is that a sign that the era of climate alarmism is coming to an end?

articles.title: Reduced air pollution is accelerating global warming, claims study
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The Earth is reflecting less sunlight and absorbing more heat than it did several decades ago. Global warming is advancing faster than predicted. Temperatures in 2023 and 2024 have exceeded the projections made by climate scientists. A new study published in Nature Communications has found that the Earth is warming.

articles.title: Planting change: Why the future of sustainability lies in partnerships of credibility and creativity
articles.author: Arabian Business
articles.summary: Climate change can seem too big to be dealt with, too soon. It's not just humans that are affected by climate change. It is also animals, plants, and the environment. It affects all of us. It has a negative impact on our environment.

articles.title: WMO: 2025 expected to rank among hottest years on record
articles.author: Bahrain News Agency
articles.summary: 2025 is likely to be among the hottest years ever recorded, ranking second or third since global records began 176 years ago. Announcement coincides with the COP30 Climate Summit in Brazil, where global leaders are discussing climate change.       .

articles.title: Amazon's boiling lake killed hundreds of dolphins, study says as climate talks open in Brazil
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Extreme heat and drought turned an Amazon lake into water hotter than a jacuzzi, killing hundreds of dolphins and exposing the growing toll of climate change on tropical ecosystems. Researchers were led by hydrologist Ayan Fleischmann of Brazil's Mamiraua Institute for Sustainable.

articles.title: Climate change boosted hurricane
articles.author: Winston-Salem Journal
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change boosted the destructive winds and rain unleashed by Hurricane Melissa and increased the temperatures and humidity that fueled the storm, according to an analysis released Thursday. The analysis was based on data from the U.S. National Center for Atmospheric Research.

articles.title: Denmark likely to be hit by severe storm surges every 3 years if climate goals fail: Report
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Denmark could be hit by severe storm surges every three years if the world fails to meet climate targets. Storm surges like the one that struck Denmark in October 2023 could occur every 3 years, according to the DMI. However, this is something Denmark can handle with various measures.

articles.title: The False Temperature Claims That Underpin the COP30 Alarmist Agenda
articles.author: The Daily Sceptic
articles.summary: The next two weeks of COP30 will see three favourite climate scares relentlessly broadcast to promote the fast-fading hard-Left Net Zero fantasy. They are breaching a 1.5°C global 'threshold' leading to runaway temperatures and human-caused tipping points producing unimaginable natural disasters.

articles.title: The Next Decade Of Danger: How Crossing 1.5�C Climate Threshold Will Change The World?
articles.author: News18
articles.summary: The increase in global temperature puts 3 billion people at risk from extreme heat, rising seas and worsening droughts worldwide, according to the UN. The world is at risk of heatwaves, rising sea levels, and worsening drought, it warns. The increase is due to the rise in the global temperature.

articles.title: Cook Islands urged to stay vigilant despite cyclone activity shifting west
articles.author: Cook Islands News
articles.summary: Pacific climate experts warn Cook Islands to remain on high alert this cyclone season. Forecasts show most tropical cyclone activity clustering west of the region. The message was reinforced at the 17th Pacific Islands Climate Outlook Forum (PICOF-17) this week.

articles.title: 2025 expected to 1 of 3 hottest years on record
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: 2025 is almost certain to be one of the three hottest years on record, according to the Copernicus Climate Change Service. October was the third-hottest October globally on record with an average temperature of -1.5 degrees Celsius.

articles.title: Xi'an City Wall gets health checkup after heavy rains
articles.author: ECNS
articles.summary: Cultural relics protection authorities in Xi'an, Shaanxi province, are implementing measures to protect the iconic Xi’an City Wall from heavy rains linked to climate change. The primary cause of damage to the wall over the years has been water.

articles.title: Empowering women in business through improved chicken in Tanzanian (CGIAR System Organization - Consortium of International Agricultural Research Centers)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Debora Elimeleki Munisi used to raise local chickens in the coastal villages of Tanzania's Lindi region, but they didn't grow well and she had to give them away. Now she raises chickens in her own farm.   -

articles.title: Cracks in Antarctic 'Doomsday Glacier' ice shelf trigger accelerated destabilization
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Thwaites Glacier in West Antarctica is one of the fastest-changing ice-ocean systems on Earth. It is often called the "Doomsday Glacier" because of its rapid change in temperature and volume of ice. It's located in the Thwaites Sea.

articles.title: The Guardian view on worsening extreme weather: the injustice of the climate crisis grows ever ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The increasing ferocity and frequency of tropical storms imposes an unbearable burden on countries such as Jamaica, especially in the Pacific Ocean region.    Jamaica is particularly vulnerable to tropical storms and hurricanes, which are becoming more frequent and destructive in nature.

articles.title: Agricultural Distortions and International Migration (IMF - International Monetary Fund)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: International migration has grown rapidly over the past two decades. This paper examines the role of agricultural distortions in shaping emigration patterns and influencing productivity and welfare in developing countries, using Guatemala as a case study. It develops a paper based on this research.

articles.title: Sandhill cranes make their return to Whitewater Draw
articles.author: STAFF REPORT
articles.summary: Large waterfowl migration is underway in southeastern Arizona. The migration is one of the most notable annual migratory phenomena in the state. The migratory phenomenon is caused by the migration of large birds of prey, such as wading birds, which are migratory.
